title: 109_hr946
content: The Independent Commission on the 2004 Coup d'Etat in Haiti is established in the legislative branch. Its duties are outlined in the Act. The Commission will investigate the US Government's involvement in the 2004 coup in Haiti, including hindering democracy, contributing to the overthrow of the elected government, and the circumstances of President Aristide's resignation and exile. The investigation will focus on the United States Government's actions regarding the 2004 coup in Haiti, including fulfilling obligations under the OAS Inter-American Democratic Charter, impeding international efforts to prevent the overthrow of the democratically-elected government, and influencing decisions at the UN Security Council. The investigation will focus on the extent of United States assistance in supporting forces opposed to the democratically-elected Government of Haiti, including the involvement of the Central Intelligence Agency and the impact of various institutes on the overthrow of President Aristide's government. The National Democratic Institute for International Affairs, funded by the United States Agency for International Development, and other organizations, are being investigated for their impact on the political process in Haiti. The investigation also includes the decision by the United States Government to discontinue bilateral assistance to Haiti and block loans, as well as the broader implications of the coup d'etat on Haiti and the Caribbean region. The Commission may examine actions of current and prior Administrations. SEC. 3. COMPOSITION OF COMMISSION. The Commission will consist of 10 members appointed by various leaders, with specific qualifications and a deadline for appointments within 45 days of the Act's enactment. The Commission shall meet as called by the Chairperson or majority of members. The Chairperson and Vice Chairperson will be elected by the Commission members. A quorum of 6 members is required, and vacancies will be filled in the same manner as the original appointment. The Commission has the power to meet as called by the Chairperson or majority of members, elect the Chairperson and Vice Chairperson, require a quorum of 6 members, and fill vacancies in the same manner as the original appointment. The Commission has the authority to conduct public hearings, meetings, and subpoena power as necessary for carrying out its duties under the Act. Public hearings must protect sensitive information, and public versions of reports must be released as required. The Commission has the authority to issue subpoenas for witnesses and evidence related to investigations. Failure to comply may result in a court order for testimony or evidence production. Subpoenas can be served within the judicial district where the person is located. The Commission has the authority to issue subpoenas in accordance with Federal Rules of Civil Procedure. It can also enter into contracts and request information from Federal agencies to fulfill its duties. The General Services Administration is required to provide assistance to the Commission. The Commission has the authority to issue subpoenas, enter contracts, and request information from Federal agencies. General Services provides administrative support, and other departments can offer services, funds, and facilities. The Commission can accept gifts, use postal services, and dispose of donations. SEC. 5. STAFF OF COMMISSION. The Chairperson of the Commission, with input from the Vice Chairperson, can appoint staff and set their compensation without following standard government hiring rules. Federal employees can also be detailed to the Commission without reimbursement. The Commission can procure consultant services at rates not exceeding those paid to a person at level IV of the Executive Schedule. SEC. 6. COMPENSATION AND TRAVEL EXPENSES. Members of the Commission may receive compensation not exceeding the daily rate of pay for a level IV position under the Executive Schedule. They are also entitled to travel expenses while performing Commission duties, following government service expense guidelines. SEC. 7. SECURITY CLEARANCES FOR COMMISSION MEMBERS AND STAFF. Federal agencies must provide security clearances to Commission members and staff. Access to classified information requires appropriate security clearance. SEC. 8. REPORTS OF COMMISSION; TERMINATION. The Commission can submit interim and final reports to Congress and the President with findings, conclusions, and recommendations. Reports will be unclassified but may include a classified annex. SEC. 9. TERMINATION. SEC. 9. TERMINATION. The Commission and its authorities will terminate 60 days after submitting the final report under section 8(b). The Commission can use this period to conclude its activities, including testifying before Congress and disseminating the final report. SEC. 10. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. $5,000,000 is authorized for fiscal year 2006 to carry out this Act, with funds remaining available until the Commission terminates.
